text.content: Click a Lesson or Activity to learn more about Reading and Writing.

In simple ways, parents and caregivers can help teach young children what print is and how it works.

Let's watch a video that shows how easy it can be to help children become more interested in words.

Young children can learn that print is all around them.

Although becoming familiar with this type of environmental print is not quite reading, helping children become excited about letters and words can be very powerful.
Reading books together is another great way to create print awareness.

Children learn:
  • Pictures in books are the story.
  • Print carries meaning.
  • Spoken words can be written.
  • Print has direction such as left to right and top to bottom in English.
  • Words have boundaries that can be separate words from each other.

Key Messages:
  • Early experience with and exposure to reading and writing correlate with a child’s future literacy development and academic success.
  • Reading aloud to children provides many important opportunities for promoting literacy and preparing children to eventually read independently.

audio.transcript: In simple ways, parents and caregivers can help teach young children what print is and how it works. Let's watch a video that shows how easy it can be to help children become more interested in words.

In this video we see that young children can learn that print is all around them. Although becoming familiar with this type of environmental print is not quite reading, helping children become excited about letters and words can be very powerful.

Reading books together is another great way to create print awareness. Since solely looking at signs and labels does not lead to learning letters and sounds, books can be another good way to expose children to these fundamental principles.

Even when parents only spend a few minutes reading each day, children learn many concepts. For example, they learn that pictures in books are the story, print carries meaning, spoken words can be written, print has direction such as left to right, and top to bottom in English, and they also learn that words have boundaries that separate words from each other. These are the fundamental principles of literacy that will prepare children to read and write.

Keep in mind that for this topic, the Key Messages are first, that early experience with and exposure to reading and writing correlate with a child’s future literacy development and academic success. And second, reading aloud to children provides many important opportunities for promoting literacy and preparing children to eventually read independently.
